to that segment of our population, to keep that
hope alive. It is to the advantage of our country
to raise that hope to the level of expectation.
It is the avowed mission of this agency to provide
adequate assistance to the poor and disadvantaged,
to assure that that possibility, the broadest of
all feasible success, does become a reality.
We must now broaden our own horizons, broaden
our existing bases of dialogue with our target
population. We need tg know more of what the poor
can "really do" with opportunity. We need to
know more of what the larger community sees as
its role in this national responsibility.
We need to know more of what the private industry,
and organized labor sectors of the community
believe their responsibility is, in the longer-
range view. We need to reach out and destroy the
isolation in which some of the poor live, by
